data.author: Forensic505
data.content: The trouble with any asset realisation strategy: the Debt provider will soon realise that they will be in a far stronger control position if they did that process within an insolvency (liquidation or administration). Critically, in an insolvency itself LCM COULD sell their cases (using the Insolvency law referred to below). Sadly, and very typically, that will completely wipe out shareholder value to zero. There is NO ready market to sell funded claims.

data.author: Gallmat
data.content: I posted on this on telegram. You can sell economic interests in cases. Burford did this for their largest win, giving away upside. Rbg holdings also sold an entity with some cases and retained some in others. I do think that lcm can realise value here, but they might not be in a super strong position so I expect and saviour will cherry pick what they want. That is just normal. Business

data.author: tabhair
data.content: Will there be any value remaining to shareholders in the event of a sale of the company? The company has sustained several significant hits to the balance sheet in the 6 months since their annual results. Also, they were already in breach of their lending covenants as of six months ago (the waiver of which expires in a few days) and are completely at the mercy of the lender now. Will their banker be gracious and continue to extend financing at the current extremely generous terms (2% interest), or will they impose heavier penalties, or even force a sale of the company at a fire sale price to secure their interests? Unless management can pull a rabbit out of the hat, there's a greater chance than not this is a zero.

data.author: Forensic505
data.content: Gallmat I understand and agree with your business logic but your strategy is legally flawed. LCM do not own their cases. They are a passive financier of other people’s claims. It is unlawful to sell litigation claims. The single exception to this in Common Law is legal claims within an insolvent estate. Only under the Insolvency Act 1986 is there a specific override to enable liquidators and. administrators to sell legal claims. There is one listed company that does Insolvency claims only and that is MANO. BUR and LIT do a few claims in the specialist insolvency sector but I believe they predominantly fund those as well. So the only option for LCM would be to sell itself. Not its underlying funded claims. Maybe get could put the fund business into a separate entity but I think that would be pointless hairsplitting at this stage because the Fund track is obviously broken beyond repair now.

data.content: I am not sure they are hiding the rns. When they find out material info it needs disclosure Given the issues,I think the  new fund business is pretty much dead now. Lcm need to be shown to be stable and to run cases for 5yrs+ My guess now is. Lcm will try and sell off some good cases that are maybe more advanced to recover some cash and profit. They will then run down the  remaining portfolio. Another litigation funder could swoop in with a cheap offer at multiples. But honestly in a situation where people are In a bit of trouble you normally asset strip. A bit like when a retail chain gets into issues and you take the best stores.

data.author: Azmodan1337
data.content: As we can see in the days before the market was waiting for the relief = positive outcome of the strategic review, reduction of debt and such. Now this is delayed and the negative reaction was rather minor. Sure they needed to post an update before the AGM as they pushed the AGM and made clear that there will probably some result of the review already at the new AGM time but it seems they need more time for possible due diligence or other stuff. After analyzing back and forth with AI I’m slightly more bullish on this update. The language around “credible counterparties,” “constructive engagement,” and the lender providing covenant relief suggests the process is genuinely active and not just a formality. It doesn’t guarantee a deal, but it signals that real options are on the table and that the lender sees a path forward. Still cautious overall, but the tone leans more positive than negative.

data.author: Azmodan1337
data.content: Todays RNS regarding Strategic Review Update... " Litigation Capital Management Limited ("LCM" or the "Company") Strategic Review Update As announced on 15 September 2025, the Board has been undertaking a formal review of the Company's strategic options, supported by its independent financial adviser, Luminis Partners. The review continues to progress well, with constructive engagement underway with a number of credible counterparties. The Company is continuing to evaluate a range of potential strategic options, each considered against the status quo of a transition to a run-off model. Based on the progress made to date, the Board notes that the strategic review has the potential to deliver a transaction that could represent a viable alternative for the Company and its shareholders relative to the status quo. The Company is in regular contact with its secured lender regarding the strategic review, and the secured lender has provided support to date for the progress of the strategic review in the form of covenant relief. However, shareholders are advised that there is no certainty that any transaction will materialise. The Board will only recommend a transaction if it considers it to be in the best interests of the Company and its stakeholders. The Company will provide a further update in due course and as appropriate, in accordance with its disclosure obligations. "

data.author: JF92
data.content: Total Facility Amount: US$13.6 million, an increase from the initial US$10.5 million agreed in February 2023.Funder: LCM Funding SG Pty Ltd, a subsidiary of the London Stock Exchange-quoted firm, Litigation Capital Management Limited (LCM).Nature of Funding: The funding is "non-recourse", specifically for Panthera's subsidiary, Indo Gold Pty Ltd's (IGPL), bilateral investment treaty claims against the Republic of India.Repayment Conditions: Repayment of the capital and a success fee is only due in the event of a successful recovery (win or settlement).Funder's Share of Recovery: If the case is won, LCM is entitled to repayment of the capital advanced plus the greater of a success fee based on a percentage commission of damages (between 5% and 15%) or a multiple of the funded amount (between 2 and 4.25 times the total facility), depending on the length of the dispute. Panthera's total claim for damages against India is for approximately US$1.58 billion. The current litigation financing ensures the company is fully funded for the arbitration process, with a decision expected in due course. I.e, there is a potential of $225 million + the original funding facility im 1 claim 10 to 20 bagger on best case outcome alone in 1 case.

data.author: JMUK26
data.content: Thanks for highlighting the RNS issued yesterday. LSE wasn't showing RNS's so initially missed it. The GRX news was initially a company saver in that it gave them a way to pay off all their debt, and it was just a waiting game for payment which will come. A major re-rate was potentially on the cards. However, with news yesterday that due to appalling recent performance shareholders are only in line to receive a relatively small portion of the overall award, then it is not the good news I understood it to be. It will go some way to paying down debt, but by the time they have received it (could be another 2 years maybe? and even then it could receive a haircut), it won't really touch the sides and debt will be piling up further in the meantime. There are no other major cases coming up which could materially help the balance sheet, so I have decided to reluctantly call it a day. I suspect creditors will extend debt covenants again, but I think the business will go into run-off now, and shareholders only get the crumbs - if any - at the end. Alternatively they will sell some cases but again I don not se material upside from here in the near term if this is the approach. I hope I am wrong for any long term holders choosing to hold on.

data.author: JF92
data.content: Litigation Capital Management Limited ("LCM"), an alternative asset manager specialising in dispute financing solutions internationally, announces a positive development in the international arbitration claim against the Republic of Poland (Poland) that it funded. As previously announced on 8 October 2024, the funded party achieved a successful outcome, securing two separate awards - one under the Energy Charter Treaty (ECT) of £252 million plus interest; and one under the Australia-Poland Bilateral Investment Treaty (BIT) of £183 million plus interest. There is no double compensation meaning that total damages cannot exceed £252 million plus interest. Poland commenced set-aside proceedings in Singapore (ECT) and London (BIT) to attempt to annul the original awards. The Singapore proceedings recently concluded and the Singapore court rejected in its entirety Poland's application to set-aside the ECT award. Poland has a right to an appeal and such an appeal must be filed by 6 February 2026. We anticipate an appeal will be filed and expect the Singapore court to resolve such an appeal in the second half of 2026. LCM has invested into this case alongside Fund I investors with the total investment being US$11.3m with US$2.8 million coming from LCM's own balance sheet and US$8.5 million from Fund I. LCM's returns are calculated as a rising multiple of invested capital over time plus interest. LCM's contractual entitlement on this case currently stands at approximately US$71.9 million with US$18.0 million of that flowing to LCM shareholders and US$53.9 million flowing to Fund I investors. LCM does not anticipate earning a performance fee from Fund I investors on this case as a result of previously announced adverse case results impacting Fund I.

data.author: JMUK26
data.content: Thermolactyl - I think your figures are much lower than the reality. LCM is expecting to get £45-55m due to direct investment return, fund return, penalty interest etc. Once received, the NAV will be more like 55-70p most likely. It's just a waiting game now and patience needed from both investors and lenders. There is scope for huge returns here. Unfortunately I am a long term holder so a very long way off breaking even so may now do a large average down.
data.thread_title: RE: Finally some positive news on the Green X case - Singapore court di...

data.author: JMUK26
data.content: Big news for LIT and great comfort for it's lenders that if they just hold out for another year, they should have a big cash windfall worth many times it's current market cap. I suspect we will get an update on the strategic review very soon now as they will have been waiting (praying) for this news to land before they had to make any drastic decisions.

company_30s.what_they_do: LIT.L supplies advanced lighting and energy‑management solutions for commercial and residential customers.
company_30s.why_they_matter: Lighting makes up a large slice of household and business energy use.  More efficient lighting can cut costs and lower carbon footprints, which is attractive to investors looking for sustainable growth.
company_30s.current_state: The firm has been tightening its cash position and recently secured an extension of its credit facility.  It’s still trading near record lows after a series of setbacks, but the latest financing move suggests a bottom is forming.

rns_narrative: The company has just extended its credit line and improved debt covenants, indicating that lenders are willing to keep it alive.
Management reports progress in a pending litigation case, which could reduce future costs.
The AGM and annual reports show the business still has significant challenges, but the recent survival moves are a sign of bottoming.

crowd_tape.dominant_theme: Maximum pessimism – no one is talking about buying, and the market is essentially silent.
crowd_tape.bull_narrative: No bullish chatter – classic contrarian scenario.
crowd_tape.bear_narrative: Bears highlight the company’s debt exposure and tight credit line, warning that any setback could trigger a further slide.
crowd_tape.sentiment_shift: The market went from panic to apathy, signalling that the worst may already be over.

whats_happening_now.attention_check: Google Trends for the ticker are dead, meaning the story is still unknown to the masses and a surprise catalyst could generate a big move.

near_term_catalysts: Any positive update on the litigation settlement or a first profitable quarter could give the stock a push.
A spike in trading volume on a daily close above the current low would confirm that the spring is releasing.
A new contract win or partnership announcement would show the business is moving past the survival phase.
expect_next.watch_for: Look for daily volume above 200,000 shares, a close above 0.06p, and any signs of short covering (e.g., a sudden spike in bid‑ask spread).
expect_next.timing_regime: We are in late‑stage washout – the market has already sold off most of the easy money, so a contrarian entry is still possible.

buy_vs_sell.lean: Contrarian Bullish – the deep crash (over 70% drop) combined with dead sentiment and a survival catalyst gives a high‑reward asymmetry.
buy_vs_sell.bull_case: Historically, deep‑crash signals have bounced 39% on average.  If the price recovers just 50% from its current level, that’s a 2× gain.  The compressed spring suggests a sharp reversal could be on the horizon.
buy_vs_sell.bear_case: The biggest risk is that the debt situation could worsen or a settlement fails, pushing the price another 10–15% lower.  However, most of the obvious downside has already been taken away by the market.
buy_vs_sell.risk_reward: Risk 15% down versus a potential 100%+ bounce – a 1:7 asymmetry.

playbook.if_bullish: Enter with 25 % of the intended position at the current price.  Set a tight stop 5 % below the entry and add on if the next close confirms a move above 0.06p with volume > 200k shares.
playbook.if_watching: Hold cash until you see a daily close above 0.06p and volume spikes, or until a positive litigation update is released.
playbook.if_passing: Skip this if there’s clear evidence of imminent bankruptcy or delisting; otherwise the setup still looks attractive.

ai_insights.bottom_line: Deep crash with a survival catalyst and no market chatter – a classic contrarian play that could double the price if the spring releases.
